results.name: Sarah Waterson
results.biography:
Sarah Waterson and Kate Richards are Sydney-based artists who have exhibited new media nationally and internationally, most recently with sub_scapeBALTIC at ISEA2004.  Before this collaboration, both worked with data in a new media framework.  Since 1991, Waterson's interactive installations have dealt with ideas of 'invisible' technology. Her most recent work, a gesture-controlled video tool (developed during a Waikato Artist Residency Program, New Zealand), explored cultural gestures and mapping. Richards has written and directed the CD-ROM Elementia, a set of 11 maps created by fictional cartographers. She was multimedia producer on the large-scale virtual mapping project TimeMap, distributed for the Museum of Sydney in collaboration with the Archaeological Computing Lab, University of Sydney. Life After Wartime (a collaboration with Ross Gibson) is a suite of new media that rework archival forensic images, texts and sounds using different codes.

Taken from PROOF exhibition 2004.

results.name: Niz Jabour
results.biography:
I was born in 1962 in a village on the Eurphrates River near Najaf in Iraq. In 1985, I graduated with a degree in applied theatre studies from the Institute of Fine Arts in Baghdad, Iraq (5 years full time study).  Shortly after completing my studies I went into exile in northern Iraq: I was waiting for political change to go back home. As soon as I crossed the border from Iraq to Iran, I was arrested, imprisoned and transferred to a detention centre (a refugee camp). I remained there for seven weeks before I was transferred to another detention centre in Tehran. I was there for 11 months before I escaped.

In the detention centre there was the constant threat of being deported back to Iraq. I got a false passport and was traveling to Syria when I was arrested again for having false papers. I was imprisoned in the north of Tehran for 4 months and 24-25 days then transferred again to the detention centre.

I escaped again to the Pakistan-Iran border; I introduced myself to UNHCR (United Nations High Commission for Refugees) and I revealed my self as an Iraqi refugee. I spent - or wasted - seven years of my life waiting for an answer from the UNHCR regarding my application for resettlement.
I was finally accepted as a refugee by Australia.
1997, March 24. I arrived in Perth, Western Australia. In 2001, I became an Australian citizen. In 2003, I finished my Master of Creative Arts at Newcastle University, Australia.

In 2004, I want back to see my homeland for the first time after 17 to 18 years in exile and I recently returned to Australia.

results.name: Institute for Applied Autonomy (IAA)
results.biography:
The Institute for Applied Autonomy (IAA) was founded in 1998 as an anonymous collective of engineers, designers, artists and activists united by the cause of individual and collective self-determination.  The group's stated mission is to develop technologies that extend the autonomy of human activists in the performance of real-world, public acts of expression.  The diminishing accessibility of public spaces for free expression and the increased omnipresence of electronic surveillance has been a key motivation for IAA research.
The IAA has exhibited at such diverse venues as the ZKM, Karlsruhe; the OK Centrum for Gegenwartskkunst, Linz; and the IEEE International Conference of Robotics and Automation.  Its most recent project TXTmob was widely used as an organisational tool by activists at the 2004 Republican National Convention in New York.

Taken from the PROOF exhibition 2004 (SW)

results.biography: Charles Spencer Chaplin III (May 5, 1925 – March 20, 1968), known professionally as Charles Chaplin Jr., was an American actor. He was the eldest son of Charlie Chaplin and Lita Grey, and is known for appearing in 1950s films such as The Beat Generation and Fangs of the Wild.

roles_in_work.title: Small world = Le Monde est petit
Beni Abbes: science in the desert
University: 900 years of inter-university co-operation in Europe
War on war = Guerre a la guerre

results.name: Ivor Montagu
results.biography: Ivor Goldsmid Samuel Montagu (23 April 1904, in Kensington, London – 5 November 1984, in Watford) was an English filmmaker, screenwriter, producer, film critic, writer, table tennis player, and Communist activist and spy in the 1930s. He helped to develop a lively intellectual film culture in Britain during the interwar years, and was also the founder of the International Table Tennis Federation.

results.name: Thorold Dickinson
results.biography: Thorold Barron Dickinson  (16 November 1903 – 14 April 1984) was a British film director, screenwriter, film editor, film producer, and Britain's first university professor of film. Dickinson's work received much praise, with fellow director Martin Scorsese describing him as "a uniquely intelligent, passionate artist... They're not in endless supply."
